pr_title: Add section on reviews to CONTRIBUTING.md

timeline.message:
Add section on reviews to CONTRIBUTING.md

The review phase is an important part of contributing to Elasticsearch, but we
do not mention it in our instructions to contributors. This commit adds some
notes on how contributions are reviewed and describes some common reasons for
rejection.

+We often reject contributions due to the low quality of the submission since

+Quality is rather subjective so it is hard to describe exactly how to avoid

+We sometimes reject contributions if we find ourselves performing a lot of
+review iterations without making significant progress. This usually indicates
+that there are a large number of small or superficial issues that we would
+normally expect to be addressed ahead of a review, and dealing with these
+leaves us with less time to consider the deeper implications of your changes.
+It is a good idea to review your contribution yourself or in your own team
+before asking us for a review. You may be surprised how many comments you can
+anticipate and address by taking a short break and then carefully looking over
+your changes again.
+
+We expect you to follow up on review comments reasonably promptly, but
+recognise that everyone has many priorities for their time and may not be able
+to respond for several days. We will understand if you find yourself without
+the time to complete your contribution, but please let us know that you have
+stopped working on it. We will try to send you a reminder if we haven't heard
+from you in a while, but may end up closing your PR if you do not respond for
+too long.

In my experience we don't always give a ton of guidance on "good first issues", but if folks come and ask we will almost certainly help. I think is important to check in even on "good first issues" just to claim them.
I think some of your concern here is around folks proposing a new feature that don't really understand what Elasticsearch is at all the right levels. Too much talking is never bad, but I think somehow this can be combined with pointing folks to "good first issue".

replies.bodyText:
I'm trying to say the opposite here: to protect our own time we might indeed decide to walk away, even if the contributor is trying their hardest, but we're simply not making progress equivalent to the time we're investing.
I think this paragraph is the hardest part of these docs: it's a really tricky balance between inclusiveness and reserving the right to walk away sometimes.

timeline.bodyText: Community PRs don't automatically hit CI, so it's hard for a contributor to know if their PR passes the full test suite without someone with CI privileges getting involved to kick off a run.  Personally, I think it's sufficient to say a change should pass ./gradlew test and ./gradlew precommit  before asking for a review, but if stuff fails in CI during the review process, that's not a reason for rejection IMHO.

replies.bodyText:
Hmm. The preceding docs in this file (and in TESTING.md) describe how to run the tests in much more detail than I think we should cover here. Changes should pass the full test suite, and I do think we should say that we expect folks to try and verify that themselves. Would s/full test suite/affected test suites/ be satisfactory? If external contributors are struggling to run the relevant test suites then that sounds like a bug.
Of course this is a "should" not a "must", I don't think we would immediately reject a good-faith contribution simply because it breaks some obscure test. The specific scenario in which a test failure should lead more directly to a quick rejection is where the PR makes some changes to production code and breaks the corresponding unit tests, indicating that the proposed changes need rethinking and that the contributor didn't even take the time run those unit tests to get that feedback for themselves.
replies.author: DaveCTurner

replies.bodyText:
I like affected test suites or related test suites better.
For better or worse, our test suite is still a little fragile (as of this writing, this PR is failing 9 tests in CI, none of which are related).  I routinely review PRs with failing tests that our team members submitted, and while there's a strong expectation that the author will fix them in that case, I don't want us to appear to have a double standard in that regard.
